posts.post_content: It's kind of expensive, despite being very fairly costed. It's three times the CMC of [Honor of the Pure](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Honor of the Pure) for, well, three times the effect and it doesn't care about creature colour. Yeah, it takes two colours to play, but one of those colours is green so there shouldn't be much trouble in getting to six mana by turn 3 or 4. I'd definitely give it a 4/5 because it really will end games quite quickly.
posts.html:
It's kind of expensive, despite being very fairly costed. It's three times the CMC of Honor of the Pure for, well, three times the effect and it doesn't care about creature colour. Yeah, it takes two colours to play, but one of those colours is green so there shouldn't be much trouble in getting to six mana by turn 3 or 4. I'd definitely give it a 4/5 because it really will end games quite quickly.

If the likes of [Gaea's Anthem](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Gaea's Anthem) are good, then this is triple that at only twice the cost. Remember this is green, and in green, you ramp.

T1: Forest, [Arbor Elf](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Arbor Elf)  
T2: Forest, [Arbor Elf](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Arbor Elf), [Avacyn's Pilgrim](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Avacyn's Pilgrim)

T4: More creatures, maybe some of those centaur tokens, or more cheap drops, then swing for win on T5.

posts.post_content: Its a nice effect, and it could win some casual and limited games, but when it comes to constructed we all know that the 6 mana slot is typically for devastating wincons like titans and Consecrated Sphinxes and all those awesome beasties, and at 6 mana this card just doesn't do enough. For any deck that has enough creatures that this would be worthwhile, at 5 mana they could use Eldrazi Monument and lose 2 power per creature, but gain the much more useful indestructibility and flying.
posts.html:
Its a nice effect, and it could win some casual and limited games, but when it comes to constructed we all know that the 6 mana slot is typically for devastating wincons like titans and Consecrated Sphinxes and all those awesome beasties, and at 6 mana this card just doesn't do enough. For any deck that has enough creatures that this would be worthwhile, at 5 mana they could use Eldrazi Monument and lose 2 power per creature, but gain the much more useful indestructibility and flying.

posts.post_content:
Basically, if you resolve [Collective Blessing](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Collective Blessing) with a decent board position and a contingency against mass-removal, you win. Assuming your opponent doesn't blow it up first. As has been mentioned by others, you should probably use it as you would an [Overrun](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Overrun). Otherwise you'll have to deal with [Detention Sphere](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Detention Sphere)s and [Oblivion Ring](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Oblivion Ring)s flying all over the place.  
  
The former's presence in standard makes token decks especially tough to build. It's hard enough with the possibility of getting [Bonfire](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Bonfire)d, [Mizzium Mortar](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mizzium Mortar)ed, [Terminus](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Terminus)ed, and/or [Supreme Verdict](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Supreme Verdict)ed; we did NOT need the [Oblivion Ring](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Oblivion Ring)s in ![White or Blue](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=WU&type=symbol) decks to suddenly start moonlighting as mass-token-removal.  
  
@FatalEagle  
  
Simplest ideal progression is probably  
T1: [Forest](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Forest), any mana dork (e.g. [Avacyn's Pilgrim](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Avacyn's Pilgrim))  
T2: a... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:
Basically, if you resolve Collective Blessing with a decent board position and a contingency against mass-removal, you win. Assuming your opponent doesn't blow it up first. As has been mentioned by others, you should probably use it as you would an Overrun. Otherwise you'll have to deal with Detention Spheres and Oblivion Rings flying all over the place.

The former's presence in standard makes token decks especially tough to build. It's hard enough with the possibility of getting Bonfired, Mizzium Mortared, Terminused, and/or Supreme Verdicted; we did NOT need the Oblivion Rings in decks to suddenly start moonlighting as mass-token-removal.

@FatalEagle
